Line 138: Line 138:
===Presidential succession===
===Presidential succession===
â
[[File:Gamal Mubarak.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Gamal Mubarak, son of Hosni Mubarak]]
+
[[File:Gamal Mubarak.jpg|thumb|upright|Gamal Mubarak, son of Hosni Mubarak]]
In 2009, US Ambassador Margaret Scobey reported uncertainty regarding presidential succession, stating "Despite incessant whispered discussions, no one in Egypt has any certainty about who will eventually succeed Mubarak nor under what circumstances."<ref name="09CAIRO874">{{cite document| last =Scobey| first = Margaret| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Scenesetter: President Mubarak's visit to Washington| id={{WikiLeaks cable|09CAIRO874}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date =2009-05-19| url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/05/09CAIRO874.html |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-01-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vq2wl2xM |archivedate=2011-01-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> She listed likely candidates, saying, "The most likely contender is presidential son [[Gamal Mubarak]] (whose profile was ever-increasing at the ruling party, until that party collapsed during [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|The Egyptian Revolution of 2011]]); some suggest that intelligence chief [[Omar Suleiman]] might seek the office, or dark horse Arab League Secretary-General [[Amr Moussa|Amre Moussa]] might run. Mubarak's ideal of a strong but fair leader would seem to discount Gamal Mubarak to some degree, given Gamal's lack of military experience, and may explain Mubarak's hands off approach to the succession question."<ref name="09CAIRO874" /> President Mubarak and his son denied this, "saying [that] a multi-candidate electoral system [[Constitution of Egypt#Presidential Elections|introduced in 2005]] has made the political process more transparent."<ref name="fatherson_deny">{{cite news | first=Alaa | last=Shahine | pages= | language =| title=Egypt's Ruling Party Tightens Grip as Mubarak Succession Nears | date=2010-11-25 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-24/egypt-s-ruling-party-tightens-grip-before-vote-as-mubarak-succession-nears.html |accessdate=2011-01-19 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vrblFIe9 |archivedate=2011-01-19 |deadurl=no }}</ref> [[Nigerian Tribune]] journalist Abiodun Awolaja described a would-be succession by Gamal Mubarak as a "hereditary pseudo-[[monarchy]]".<ref name="NigTrib_pseudomon">{{cite news | first=Abiodun | last=Awolaja | pages= | language =| title=Between Nigeria and Egypt's presidential crises | date=2010-03-24 | publisher=[[Nigerian Tribune]] | url=http://www.tribune.com.ng/index.php/politics/3017-between-nigeria-and-egypts-presidential-crises |accessdate=2011-01-19 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vrcMHuEg |archivedate=2011-01-19 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Ambassador Scobey summarised Mubarak's vision of the presidential succession, stating, "Indeed, he seems to be trusting to God and the ubiquitous military and civilian security services to ensure an orderly transition."<ref name="09CAIRO874" /> The National Democratic Party of Egypt continued to state that Hosni Mubarak was to be the party's only candidate to the 2011 Presedential Elections. Mubarak declared on February 1, 2011 that he had no intention to run in the presidential race at the end of 2011. When this declaration failed to ease the protests, Mubarak's vice president stated that Gamal Mubarak, the son, will not run for president. With the escalation of the demonstration and the fall of Mubarak, a former influential figure in the National Democratic Party Hamdy El-Sayed, claimed that Gamal Mubarak intended to forcibly take over his father's position, assisted in that by the then Interior Minister, Habib El-Adly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=394434 |title=Ø­ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙØ³ÙØ¯: Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙØ§Ù ÙØ¯Ø¨Ø± ÙØ§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¨ Ø¹ÙÙ Ø£Ø¨ÙÙ Ø¨Ø¯Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ - Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ |publisher=Shorouknews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-15}}</ref>
In 2009, US Ambassador Margaret Scobey reported uncertainty regarding presidential succession, stating "Despite incessant whispered discussions, no one in Egypt has any certainty about who will eventually succeed Mubarak nor under what circumstances."<ref name="09CAIRO874">{{cite document| last =Scobey| first = Margaret| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Scenesetter: President Mubarak's visit to Washington| id={{WikiLeaks cable|09CAIRO874}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date =2009-05-19| url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/05/09CAIRO874.html |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-01-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vq2wl2xM |archivedate=2011-01-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> She listed likely candidates, saying, "The most likely contender is presidential son [[Gamal Mubarak]] (whose profile was ever-increasing at the ruling party, until that party collapsed during [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|The Egyptian Revolution of 2011]]); some suggest that intelligence chief [[Omar Suleiman]] might seek the office, or dark horse Arab League Secretary-General [[Amr Moussa|Amre Moussa]] might run. Mubarak's ideal of a strong but fair leader would seem to discount Gamal Mubarak to some degree, given Gamal's lack of military experience, and may explain Mubarak's hands off approach to the succession question."<ref name="09CAIRO874" /> President Mubarak and his son denied this, "saying [that] a multi-candidate electoral system [[Constitution of Egypt#Presidential Elections|introduced in 2005]] has made the political process more transparent."<ref name="fatherson_deny">{{cite news | first=Alaa | last=Shahine | pages= | language =| title=Egypt's Ruling Party Tightens Grip as Mubarak Succession Nears | date=2010-11-25 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-24/egypt-s-ruling-party-tightens-grip-before-vote-as-mubarak-succession-nears.html |accessdate=2011-01-19 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vrblFIe9 |archivedate=2011-01-19 |deadurl=no }}</ref> [[Nigerian Tribune]] journalist Abiodun Awolaja described a would-be succession by Gamal Mubarak as a "hereditary pseudo-[[monarchy]]".<ref name="NigTrib_pseudomon">{{cite news | first=Abiodun | last=Awolaja | pages= | language =| title=Between Nigeria and Egypt's presidential crises | date=2010-03-24 | publisher=[[Nigerian Tribune]] | url=http://www.tribune.com.ng/index.php/politics/3017-between-nigeria-and-egypts-presidential-crises |accessdate=2011-01-19 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vrcMHuEg |archivedate=2011-01-19 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Ambassador Scobey summarised Mubarak's vision of the presidential succession, stating, "Indeed, he seems to be trusting to God and the ubiquitous military and civilian security services to ensure an orderly transition."<ref name="09CAIRO874" /> The National Democratic Party of Egypt continued to state that Hosni Mubarak was to be the party's only candidate to the 2011 Presedential Elections. Mubarak declared on February 1, 2011 that he had no intention to run in the presidential race at the end of 2011. When this declaration failed to ease the protests, Mubarak's vice president stated that Gamal Mubarak, the son, will not run for president. With the escalation of the demonstration and the fall of Mubarak, a former influential figure in the National Democratic Party Hamdy El-Sayed, claimed that Gamal Mubarak intended to forcibly take over his father's position, assisted in that by the then Interior Minister, Habib El-Adly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=394434 |title=Ø­ÙØ¯Ù Ø§ÙØ³ÙØ¯: Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙØ§Ù ÙØ¯Ø¨Ø± ÙØ§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¨ Ø¹ÙÙ Ø£Ø¨ÙÙ Ø¨Ø¯Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ - Ø¨ÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ |publisher=Shorouknews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-15}}</ref>
